utterances.text: Datastories is supported by Tableau software, helping people see and understand their data. Get answers from interactive dashboards wherever you go. For your free trial, visit Tableau software at Tableau software.com Datastories. That's Tableau software.com Datastories.

Do this, like these case studies, you know, I said before to you. utterances.text: We can see. So if you guys have any suggestions, let us know.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Cool. So I think we have to go.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, I think this was in Paris was great. I'm really excited. I'm actually a little sad that it's over, but I'm also relieved because I'm so tired. It's been a real marathon on being.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini

chapters.summary: Enrico Data Stories is reporting from Biz 2014, from Paris. We will be reporting every day from the start of the conference until the end. We'll try and record a snippet every day. And sort of Frankenstein an episode out of that later.
chapters.headline: Enrico Data Stories is reporting from Biz 2014 in Paris

chapters.summary: This is basically the academic conference on information visualization, or visualization in general. There are three main tracks: scientific visualization, visual analytics, and the infovis. Moritz gave a tutorial on everything except the chart. It was quite, quite well received in the end.
chapters.headline: Information visualization conference is basically the academic conference on information visualization

chapters.summary: In visualization we are very much concerned with clarity. You can be as clear as you want, but still communicate distorted information. Truthfulness doesn't depend exclusively on the visualization side of things. How do you teach people how to do this?
chapters.headline: There was a keynote by Alberto Cairo on truthfulness in data visualization

chapters.summary: If we want to make people data literate, we cannot just show them stuff all the time. We need to do workshops and hackathons, activities where they actually create their own data. Can we meet in the middle?
chapters.headline: I come more and more to the conviction that if we want to make data literate

chapters.summary: So what else should we say? Tell about this? I think, of course, today we had a very large set of papers. I was in two sessions. So I felt, I feel very smart right now. So things are good.
chapters.gist: A few words on the conference
chapters.headline: Today we had a very large set of papers. I don't know if you attended any session

chapters.summary: A student from Jarke van Wijk's group presented a network visualization. It's multivariate network exploration and presentation from detail to overview via selections and aggregations. Interesting tool.
chapters.headline: A student from Jarke van Wijk's group presented a network visualization

chapters.summary: I was quite impressed with the domino tool. It was a very impressive tool for collecting or aligning multiple views of the same data set quickly. Tomorrow we will actually meet real data stories, listeners in a room.
chapters.headline: I was quite impressed with the domino tool. Was it domino

chapters.summary: Long time guest Robert Cazara. Nobody's surprised when Robert is here. It's basically a furniture here. That's a compliment. What can you do?
chapters.headline: Enrico welcomes long time guest Robert Cazara

chapters.summary: So we are here still at Visweek. We had a great meetup yesterday with a few of our listeners. And we got a lot of good tips. Lots of good feedback, advice. So very nice.
chapters.headline: We had a great meetup yesterday with a few of our listeners

chapters.summary: Enrico: How do you like the conference? Robert: I like it. It feels like it's a stronger infovis this year than the last two or so. And also, it seems like the presentations are getting better.
chapters.gist: Winter Science Conference 2017: the conference itself
chapters.headline: Robert: It seems like the presentations are getting better this year

chapters.summary: Today's Thursday. What happened on Wednesday and what happened on Thursday. Should we start from Wednesday? Sure. Okay, we go in chronological order.
chapters.gist: How to talk through the program
chapters.headline: When should we go through the program today? Should we start from Wednesday

chapters.summary: An interesting paper had had them build essentially an interactive version of the reorderable matrix. Do you think, was it primarily an homage or do you think some work will continue along these lines?
chapters.gist: The Bertin Matresses: Interactivity and Authorship
chapters.headline: An interesting paper had had them build an interactive version of the reorderable matrix

chapters.summary: Bertin was a famous french cartographer that published this super famous book in our community called La Semiologie Graphique Graphic. He basically established all the fundamentals of visualization. Every visual representation can be decomposed into visual primitives.
chapters.headline: Bertin basically established all the fundamentals of visualization

chapters.summary: A paper I heard was well received on visualizing statistical mix effects in Simpsons paradox. Unfortunately, I missed the presentation. This year, maybe for the first time, there are much more applications and systems and less techniques.
chapters.gist: Other good papers from the conference
chapters.headline: Winston presented a tool that lets you create multiple views on a single canvas

chapters.summary: interactive latency on exploratory visual analysis sounds really, really interesting. It certainly led to people exploring less because it was just more annoying. But when they asked people afterwards, a third didn't actually notice a delay. It could be useful sometimes to be slower and to be more deliberate.
chapters.gist: Interactive latency and exploratory visual analysis
chapters.headline: Interactive latency may hinder exploratory visual analysis, study finds

chapters.summary: A user study comparing standard error bars with other kind of encodings. Found traditional way scientists used to show error bars doesn't work very well. Will see a lot of wiring plots. People post a lot more information about how to reach their work.
chapters.headline: User study compared standard error bars with other encodings

chapters.summary: Next one in the same session. for experiments on the perception of bar charts. They basically repeated some of the classic Cleveland studies. The goal of this work is more to understand why they get that. What are the issues there?
chapters.gist: Bar charts and perception of them
chapters.headline: Next one in the same session is on perception of bar charts

chapters.summary: A paper on the algebraic process for visualization design. The idea is to look at visualizations from a perspective of when the data changes, how is that reflected in the visualization. I'm actually planning to use it for, in my class to teach my students.
chapters.gist: The Algebraic Process for Visualization Design
chapters.headline: Algebraic process for visualization design is brilliant. What's your take on that

chapters.summary: There was a panel on challenges in financial visualization. Do you remember any payroll? Financial visualization, Robert? It's rare, right? There have been a few, but I think it's probably been ten years since the last one.
chapters.headline: There was a panel on challenges in financial visualization on Wednesday

chapters.summary: Data stories is supported by Tableau software, helping people see and understand their data. Tableau lets people connect to any kind of data and visualize it on the fly. They also supported the conference, so they were sponsored.
chapters.headline: Data stories is supported by Tableau software helping people see and understand data

chapters.summary: There was a paper on staggered animation that I thought was pretty good. I was really surprised by the methodology that they adopted. Methodology is amazing. I would love to see it replicated in future years.
chapters.gist: Monte Carlo simulation in data visualization
chapters.headline: There was a paper on staggered animation that I thought was pretty good

chapters.summary: A tool called combing the communication hairball. Visualizing large parallel execution traces using logical time. It's a nice high end tool for monitoring parallel computation processes. Do you have an idea if the tool is. available on the web?
chapters.gist: Visualizing large parallel execution traces using logical time
chapters.headline: Visualizing large parallel execution traces using logical time. It's really good

chapters.summary: Robert: What they were trying to do is figure out what's the right palette of shapes and colors and sizes for encoding data. He says the larger the size gets, the less difference we see between the size. Robert: They also created a library that you can download and use directly.
chapters.headline: What's the right palette of shapes and colors for encoding data

chapters.summary: Study compares many different chart types you could use for judging correlation. It follows a very primitive, let's. Say perception law, which is the Weber's law. For the positive correlation, they're terrible. And slope graphs are terrible.
chapters.gist: How to Judge Correlation using Weber's Law
chapters.headline: One study looked at how well people can judge correlation between variables

chapters.summary: Robert: I think the whole area of understanding and measuring visual literacy is super important. Especially now that visualization is exposed to a very large segment of the population. The paper aims to create a test to measure how literate a person is in terms of being able to read visualizations.
chapters.headline: Robert Post: I think measuring visual literacy is super important

chapters.summary: What I'm wondering is, honestly, is visual literacy a one dimensional thing? Like, can you express your literacy in one number? And this is tied together with talking about data literacy and also teaching people. I think it's our big challenge.
chapters.gist: Is Visual Literacy a One-dimensional Thing?
chapters.headline: Can you express your literacy in one number? I'm not convinced

chapters.summary: Robert: Lots of tools, good evaluation, no position papers, great slides. I think the divide between practitioners and academics is getting narrower and narrower. Our workshop on web visualization was packed. I am super psyched about what will come the next year when they're all native stuff.
chapters.gist: A week in the web: Chicago
chapters.headline: Robert: I think the divide between practitioners and academics is getting narrower

chapters.summary: Still in Paris. Conference has just ended. Friday looks pretty sad outside. Everything's being disassembled. We found a quiet room here, halfway quiet. They might kick us out at some. Point, so I think we should just wrap it up.
chapters.headline: Still in Paris. Conference has just ended. Friday looks pretty sad outside

chapters.summary: This conference start way too early. The main highlight today was the capstone from Barbara Tversky. She said that interaction disrupts storytelling. Morris missed the paper sessions as well. But the conference was really good. Lots of good people.
chapters.headline: Barbara Tversky talked about how interaction disrupts storytelling

chapters.summary: Some of these papers have a very clear practical impact. Some of them are useful for teaching visualization as well. The algebraic process one, I think it's going to be a very interesting model to teach in class.
chapters.gist: Mental models in the visualization world
chapters.headline: Some of these papers are useful for teaching visualization as well

chapters.summary: What did we see in Rico? Like, is there anything. There are many things we didn't see. Probably a lot of good sessions. And then there was an amazing Bertin exhibit which I just visited very briefly.
chapters.gist: What did we see in Puerto Rico?
chapters.headline: There are many things we didn't see in Rico

chapters.summary: I think the biggest trend, as I said, is even higher quality. I have seen for the first time lots of really good sessions on user studies. If you have suggestions for good topics, rate us on iTunes.
chapters.headline: Are there things that were more present at last year's conferences that have disappeared

chapters.summary: Once again, there should be a meetup. I think if you have more comments or suggestions for how we can improve. Tiger quality, more episodes or. Was transcripts, transcript, having transcripts, things like this. If you guys have any suggestions, let us know.
chapters.gist: Thanks for your feedback on the show
chapters.headline: I think we can do much better. So if you guys have any suggestions, let us know

chapters.summary: Next show we will do with Tamara Munzner, who finally put out her book. After that, we have an episode lined up with Nicholas Shelton. We will manage to talk about quantified self. Eventually measuring yourself and making you as a data point.
chapters.headline: Vivalini: I'm glad this trip is over. I'm exhausted. It's been a real marathon on being
